clauses.text: Students can find their assessments listed in Canvas or in the course guide. Canvas provides detailed information such as due dates, rubrics, and submission methods.
subclauses: Log in to Canvas using your RMIT ID and password.
Select Courses in the navigation bar.
Select Assignments to view all assessment tasks.
Select each assignment to see details including due date and rubric.

clauses.text: In each course guide, the section Overview of assessment outlines the types of assessments students must undertake.
Some courses include online timed assessments or on-campus exams scheduled during the assessment period. Refer to the Timed Assessments and On-Campus Exams page for details.
Most assessments at RMIT are submitted online via Canvas using Turnitin software. Submissions include an online assessment declaration.
subclauses: Go to the Canvas webpage for detailed submission instructions.
Ensure that all files are uploaded correctly before the due date.

clauses.text: If you encounter technical faults when submitting online, take a screenshot of the error message and record the time it occurred. Notify your teacher and contact IT Service Connect.
Some assessments must be submitted physically, such as creative works or artefacts. Physical submissions must include a completed and signed cover sheet and declaration.
When submitting work for assessment, students must agree to the Declaration and Statement of Authorship, affirming the originality of their work and understanding of plagiarism.
subclauses: The assessment is original and not copied from other sources except where acknowledged.
No impersonation or unauthorized collaboration occurred.
Permission is granted for assessment responses to be reproduced and archived for plagiarism detection.
Plagiarism is a serious academic offence that can lead to exclusion.
Students must cite all material appropriately and not assist others in plagiarism.

clauses.text: If the declaration is not agreed to or signed, the assessment will not be valid and will not count toward the final result.
Teaching staff will provide feedback to assist in improving performance. Students should receive feedback within 10 working days of submission.
subclauses: Students may request feedback if it is not received within the timeframe.
Feedback may be provided in various forms including class discussions, rubrics, one-on-one sessions, or group feedback.

clauses.text: Rubrics outline individual assessment criteria and enable consistent, transparent marking. Teachers use rubrics to show how each criterion was met.
Students are encouraged to reflect on feedback to improve future performance and achievement levels.

sections.section_title: Review and Appeal of Final Course Results

clauses.text: If students believe there has been an error impacting their final result, they may request a review (stage 1) followed by an appeal (stage 2) if the issue remains unresolved.
subclauses: Stage 1 Review: Contact the Course Coordinator or Program Manager to request a review within 5 working days of the result publication.
Stage 2 Appeal: If unsatisfied after stage 1, submit an appeal via the RMIT appeals portal.
More information is available in the Appeals and Assessment Processes, Chapter 7.
